findings.title: Broken or deprecated cipher algorithm
findings.description: Code actively uses a broken cipher algorithm (DES, RC4, RC2, Blowfish, or ECB mode) as a cipher call argument.
findings.risk: DES has a 56-bit key space (brute-forceable). RC4 has multiple practical biases. ECB mode leaks data patterns. These algorithms MUST NOT be used for new implementations.
findings.confidenceRationale: The cipher name appears as a function call argument â€” this is active usage, not a comment or documentation reference.
findings.recommendation: Use AES-256-GCM or ChaCha20-Poly1305 for symmetric encryption. Never use DES, RC4, RC2, Blowfish, or ECB mode in new code.

findings.title: DES/3DES cipher usage detected
findings.description: Code references DES or 3DES encryption algorithms.
findings.risk: DES is broken and 3DES is deprecated due to weak security margins and practical attacks.
findings.confidenceRationale: DES/3DES references are explicit and widely considered unsafe for new implementations.
findings.recommendation: Use modern ciphers (AES-GCM or ChaCha20-Poly1305) and avoid DES/3DES entirely.

findings.title: DES/3DES cipher usage detected
findings.description: Code references DES or 3DES encryption algorithms.

findings.recommendation: Use modern ciphers (AES-GCM or ChaCha20-Poly1305) and avoid DES/3DES entirely.
findings.snippet: byte[] iv = random.generateSeed(8); // DES requires 8 byte keys

findings.title: Base64-encoded value near secret-like key
findings.description: A base64-encoded value was assigned to a secret-like key.
findings.risk: Base64 is often used to encode secrets, not protect them. If sensitive, this may expose credentials.
findings.confidenceRationale: Base64 values are common and ambiguous without context.
findings.recommendation: Confirm whether the value is sensitive. If it is, rotate it and store it securely outside source control.

findings.title: Stack traces may be logged with sensitive context
findings.description: Code logs stack traces or error objects that may contain sensitive context.
findings.risk: Stack traces can leak secrets in error messages, internal file paths, query strings, and PII depending on error sources.
findings.confidenceRationale: Logging errors is normal; risk depends on what is included and redaction configuration.
findings.recommendation: Log structured error codes and minimal context. Use centralized error reporting with redaction controls.
